TEXT.Italian: Ophelia ha l'opportunità di ricevere il Dono se sta guidando gli Eredi, ottenendo i tratti [LINK=TRAIT_DEATHTOUCHED]Toccato dalla Morte[\LINK], [LINK=TRAIT_AGNOSTIC]Agnostico[\LINK], e [LINK=TRAIT_PERSONALITY_CULT]Culto della Personalità[\LINK]. La hanno abbandonata. Erano scappati da dove lei era rimasta. Smarrita, al freddo e sola, Ophelia aveva visto lo spargimento di sangue causato sia dagli uomini che dai demoni, e in questo inferno, i ricordi si mischiavano tra loro in tal modo che neppure lei riusciva a distinguere il demone dall'uomo. Persino Donal, colui che era rimasto indietro, era brutale quanto se non anche più letale dei demoni che la inseguivano per le distese infernali. Ma ne demone ne uomo la avrebberò mai trovata. Essendo stata abbandonata, Ophelia aveva abbandonato molti degli approcci fanatici dei Bannor alla sopravvivenza. E fu per questo che, per la prima volta da quando aveva combattuto al fianco di Capria come Donna di Rinforzo, sentì l'assenza dell'impeto di speranza in posti come questi. In questo inferno, in cui era stata abbandonata, lei si era adattata. "Forse sei molto più simile a quello stolto di Donal più di quanto tu voglia ammettere, Ms. Rosenthal." La voce fu rapida a spezzare il suo umore mentre si guardava attorno, la lama nella sua mano era scheggiata e macchiata dal sangue di molti. Ma non c'era altro cui puntarla che vento pieno di polvere, nessuno che gli sussurrava all'orecchio, nessuna bestia che meritasse la sua spada nel petto. I suoi occhi guizzavano da una parte all'altra, non vedendo nulla all'orizzonte. Non vedendo niente, ma sentendo il suono di una corda rompersi, di rocce che cascavano l'una su l'altra e l'inevitabile frastuono mentre le sue trappole venivano distrutte da qualcosa. Il rumore echeggiò nelle terre desolate, mentre Ophelia rimaneva a gaurdare ore preziose del suo lavoro venir distrutte. Mentre l'ultima roccia della frana cadeva, sapeva che non avrebbe smesso. Quel fugace momento di speranza era sparito. Era stato sostituito da qualcosa di molto più sinistro. Una fredda sensazione di bruciore nella sua anima. Forse erano le machinazioni di innumerevoli generazioni che l'avevano spinta sino a questo punto, o magari è stato qualcosa'altro. Ma la fuga era l'unica opzione. La sua testa si riempì da sola di idee, piani, teorie che non aveva mai pensato prima. Ma ogni idea, ogni pensiero, era estraneo e malizioso. E furono queste idee a sussurrargli all'orecchio l'unica via per uscire dall'inferno, doveva essere cacciata via. La strada per il dominio di Mulcarn era troppo lenta, aveva bisogno di essere libera da questo squallido posto. I seducenti sussurri di libertà riempirono la sua mente mentre le lande desolate diventavano più piccole per lei, ogni passo non prendeva più le energie di cento e ogni giorno passato nella foschia rossa diventata sempre più corto mentre si scopriva a provare un'estasi quasi macabra nel rompere non la forza ma la volonta di ogni demone. Si deliziava della confusione e frustrazione che il nemico provava quando perdeva la sua traccia, e rideva della loro incompetenza mentre lei seguiva i venti sussurranti degli inferni. Il tempo non aveva alcun significato per Ophelia mentre scivolava da un piano infernale all'altro, muovendosi nelle ombre e passando non vista. I demoni non gli prestavano più attenzione, scambiandola per un'altro supplicante mentre passava attraverso i vari piani per raggiungere il suo obiettivo finale, il Piano di Cerdiwen. I sussurri gli avevano detto dove andare, come fare per andarci, i sigilli e i misteri che avrebbe dovuto decifrare e infine, la strada per muoversi nel piano. Ma nessun sussurro, ne falsa speranza, o desiderio bruciante l'avrebbe potuta preparare al passaggio nell'abisso. Vide ogni cosa in quel vortice, segreti che frantumarono la sua mente ancora e ancora, ciò che percepiva andava in frantumi in ogni istante. Percepì la tortura di Furia dal punto di vista dell'angelo Balseraph, guardò attraverso gli occhi di Nemed mentre si contorceva per via di un dolore lancinante sotto il controllo di Os-Gabella, e sentì Flauros bucare la sua pelle come fosse Taerry, la povera ragazza Calabim che non era altro che un giocattolo per l'aristocratico. Ma Ophelia era stata tutte quelle persone e aveva visto tutto attraverso i loro occhi. Il loro dolore, le loro paure, i loro rimpianti, ma anche le loro speranze, i loro sogni, e i futuri che sarebbero potuti essere. Ophelia non sapeva se fosse per via dei sussurri o per via di Cerdiwen stessa che stava tormentando l'intruso Bannor, ma non se ne curò per molto quando i suoi polmoni si riempirono di un'aria fredda e frizzante. Era di nuovo su Erebus. Ma aveva visto ciò che vedevano milioni di anime, guardò addirittura dentro lo stesso Avatar della Rabbia mentre veniva creato. Cose che un semplice mortale non dovrebbe mai vedere. E il suo stesso essere non era più parte di lei. Il suo sguardo, un tempo sia spaventato che speranzoso era ora sinistro e distante. La sua voce era controllata e il suo tono era impertinente e veloce, il suo umore era repentino, ma le sue reazioni pensate ed eseguite con precisione. Lei non era più Ophelia Rosenthal, ma piuttosto la somma di tutto ciò che aveva visto.
TEXT.Spanish: Ophelia has the opportunity to take the Gift if leading the Scions, adding the [LINK=TRAIT_DEATHTOUCHED]Deathtouched[\LINK], [LINK=TRAIT_AGNOSTIC]Agnostic[\LINK], and [LINK=TRAIT_PERSONALITY_CULT]Personality Cult[\LINK] traits. They had left her. They had escaped where she had remained. Lost, cold, and alone, Ophelia had seen the bloodshed caused by both man and demon alike, and in this hell, the memories faded together where she could neither separate the demon from the man. Even Donal, the one whom had stayed behind, was as brutal and if not more lethal than the demons that chased her through the wastes. But neither demon nor man would ever find her. Having been abandoned, Ophelia had abandoned many of the Bannor's fanatical approaches to survival. And it was because of this that for the first time since she had fought alongside Capria as a Secondline-Woman, she had felt the surge of hope that was nonexistent in the place like this. In this hell where she had been abandoned, she had adapted. "Perhaps you are more like that fool Donal than you care to admit, Ms. Rosenthal." The voice was quick to shatter her mood as she spun around, the blade in her hand chipped and stained with the blood of many. But it pointed at nothing but the dusty winds, no foe whispering in her ear, no beast that warranted her sword through its chest. Her eyes darted to and fro, seeing nothing on the horizon. Seeing nothing but hearing the sounds of rope tearing, rocks tumbling against one another and the inevitable shattering as her traps had been destroyed by something. The sounds echoed across the broken fields, as Ophelia stood there watching precious hours of her labor be destroyed. As the last rock tumbled down from her makeshift rockslide, she knew that this would go on. That fleeting moment of hope was gone. It had been replaced by something far more sinister. A cold burning sensation on her soul. Perhaps it was the machinations of countless generations that had pushed her to this edge, or perhaps it was something else. But escape was the only option. Her head filled itself with ideas, plots, theories that she hadn't conceived before. But each idea, each thought, was foreign and malicious. And it was these ideas that had whispered in her ear the only way out of hell, was to be gated out. The path up Mulcarn's domain was too slow- she needed to be free of this wretched place. The seductive whispers of freedom filled her mind as the wastelands grew smaller to her, each step no longer taking the effort of a hundred and each day spent in the red haze she had been left in grew shorter as she found herself taking an almost macabre ecstasy from breaking each demon not of their strength, but of their will. She relished in the confusion and frustration as the enemy lost her trail, and laughed at their incompetence as she followed the whispering winds of the hells. Time held no meaning for Ophelia as she slipped from one vault, moving in the shadows and slipping by unnoticed. Demons no longer paid heed to her, mistaking her for another petitioner as she pushed between vaults and into her ultimate goal- the Vault of Cerdiwen. The whispers had told her where to go, how to get there, the sigils and mysteries she would need to decipher and ultimately, the way to navigate the vault. But no whisper, no false hope, no burning desire could prepare her as she slipped into the unmentionable abyss. She saw everything in the maelstrom and webways, secrets that pushed her mind to break and then break again, her perceptions shattered every instant. She perceived Furia's torture from the view of the Balseraph angel, gazed through the eyes of Nemed as he twisted and writhed in excruciating pain under the will of Os-Gabella, and felt Flauros pierce her flesh as Taerry, the poor Calabim girl whom was nothing more than a plaything the aristocrat. But to Ophelia, she was all of these people and had seen everything through their eyes. Their pain, their fears, their sorrows, but also their hopes, their dreams, and the futures that could have been. Ophelia didn't know if this was from the whispers or from Cerdiwen herself preying upon the trespassing Bannor, but she no longer cared as her lungs were filled with cold, crisp air. She was on Erebus again. But she had seen the visions of millions of souls, gazed into the very Avatar of Wrath as he was being formed. Things a mere mortal was never meant to see. And her very being was no longer part of her. Her gaze, where it had once been both frightened but and hopeful was now left sinister and distant. Her voice was controlled and her tone pert and quick, her temper now short but her reactions to be thought out and executed with precision. She was no longer Ophelia Rosenthal, but rather the sum of what she had seen.

TEXT.French: Sabathiel

TEXT.English: [TAB]Shaddis slipped quietly into the room. Although not comparable to the vast antechambers and lofty halls of the public part of the Halls of Sabathiel, the room was large enough, roughly cubic and a good six meters from floor to roof. The roof was vaulted, with supporting columns built into the four walls, dividing each wall into three segments.[PARAGRAPH:1]The room was also plunged into darkness, something which simply drew your attention to the fact that the huge figure lying on a carved stone bed in the centre of the room was emitting a faint glow. Sabathiel was sleeping again. He'd probably been sleeping since last Shaddis spoke to him, two weeks ago. [PARAGRAPH:1]It wasn't really sleep, Shaddis reflected. He wasn't quite sure what it was. It was like Sabathiel's body was there, on the stone bed, but his mind and soul weren't. The Deacon of Winds had never asked Sabathiel where his mind went when he lay like that. He wasn't sure he wanted to know. [PARAGRAPH:1]As Shaddis approached, there was a sucking sound, like a sharp intake of air, and Sabathiel sat bolt upright with startling suddenness. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Something has happened."[PARAGRAPH:1]The voice sounded like a million voices speaking softly at the same time, and it carried a note of simultaneous accusation and certainty that infuriated Shaddis. Sabathiel was scrutinizing him, probably finding out what was wrong even before Shaddis had a chance to say it. And the angel was right, both in the statement and in the accusatory tone. Something HAD happened, and Shaddis was at fault, albeit indirectly. [PARAGRAPH:1]"They will be punished, of course. We must teach them that they cannot defy Law and hope to avoid repercussions. But I am disappointed in you, deacon. You knew about this. You could have stopped it earlier." [PARAGRAPH:1]Shaddis bowed his head in shame. He had known, but he hadn't found it important. Dealing with it at this early stage would have required taking appalling measures. So he had left the problem alone, hoping it would burn itself out. Instead it had exploded. The cleaning up would be a mess.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel floated to his feet. As he did, the room erupted with multi-hued light. The sight never ceased to awe Shaddis. Every section of wall was now a huge window looking out across a landscape far below. It was as if the room was at the top of an impossibly tall tower. But the view was not uniform. Each window overlooked a different landscape: In one window, all you could see was mountains, ice and snow. Another showed rolling hills, fields and peaceful pastures. A third looked out across an endless desert. [PARAGRAPH:1]The angelic ruler of the Bannor drifted across to a window that showed the sprawling urban vista of the capital. He stood there in silence, his hands clasped behind his back, for quite some time. Shaddis didn't speak. Holding a conversation with Sabathiel was a frustrating affair-the angel knew what you were going to say before you said it, and generally answered before you even had a chance to open your mouth. So the Deacon waited patiently for his master to break the silence. [PARAGRAPH:1]Finally, Sabathiel let out a long, shuddering sigh. It reminded Shaddis of a wind whistling through a mountain pass. Still facing his city, Sabathiel started to speak: [PARAGRAPH:1]"I don't blame you. After all, you're only human. You're all only human. Invaluable tools in Junil's service, but still only mortal flesh, fallible and prone to faltering. Sometimes, my friend, mercy must take a back seat to peace, stability and Law. This was one of those times, and you failed to recognize it. You reached the limits of your human capacities. I'm not angry. I have no real reason to be disappointed either. But you are a product of my people, of my children, those whom I lead into the light, those I protected through Mulcarn's reign. I suppose... I suppose I have expected too much from you." [PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel paused. To gather his thoughts, perhaps. Who knew? His mind appeared to work on an entirely different plane. While humans had to stumble through their choices, hoping the one they made was the best possible, the angel simply knew. He was capable of total mercilessness, of deceit and exquisite cruelty, but the results of an action commanded by Sabathiel would always be better than any alternative course of action could have brought. The angel, however heartless and wrong he seemed at the time, was always right. The window suddenly started showing many different views, flickering past at an astonishing speed. [PARAGRAPH:1]"So much to watch. So many to care for. So many things that can go awry. I wish, oh, how I wish, I could take a more direct part in the affairs of my people. These things would not happen. I would be there to stop them. But I am not strong enough. Not yet. I need to conserve what little strength I still possess. Someday, after you are gone, perhaps, but some day soon, I will need it. We will all need it."

TEXT.German: [TAB]Shaddis schlüpfte leise in den Raum. Obwohl dieser nicht mit den enormen Vorräumen und erhabenen Gewölben der öffentlichen Bereiche der Sabathiels Hallen vergleichbar war, so war der würfelförmige und etwa sechs Meter hohe Raum dennoch von komfortabler Größe. Das gewölbte Dach wurde von zwölf Säulen getragen, welche so in die vier Wände eingearbeitet waren, dass sie jede Wand in drei Bereiche teilten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Raum war in Dunkelheit gehüllt. Dadurch wurde die Aufmerksamkeit des Betrachters auf die Tatsache gelenkt, dass die auf einem aus Stein gemeißelten Bett in der Mitte des Raumes liegende riesige Gestalt ein sanftes Licht ausstrahlte. Sabathiel schlief wieder oder vermutlich immer noch seit Shaddis das letzte Mal vor etwa zwei Wochen mit ihm gesprochen hatte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Es war kein wirklicher Schlaf, überlegte Shaddis. Er war nicht ganz sicher was es eigentlich war. Es schien, als wäre nur Sabathiels Körper dort auf dem steinernen Bett, nicht aber sein Geist und seine Seele. Der Diakon des Windes hatte Sabathiel nie gefragt, wohin seine Gedanken wanderten, wenn er so dalag wie jetzt. Er war sich nicht einmal sicher, ob er es überhaupt wissen wollte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Als Shaddis sich näherte, hörte er ein saugendes Geräusch, gleich einem schneidendes Einatmen, und Sabathiel saß plötzlich kerzengrade aufrecht.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Es ist etwas passiert"[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Stimme klang wie zahllose verschiedene Stimmen, die leise alle auf einmal sprachen. Sie übermittelte einen Hauch von Anklage und gleichzeitig Bestimmtheit, was Shaddis wütend machte. Sabathiel musterte ihn prüfend, vermutlich um herauszufinden was es war, noch bevor Shaddis eine Chance hatte, es zu sagen. Und der Engel hatte Recht, sowohl mit der Feststellung, als auch mit dem vorwurfsvollen Ton. Es war TATSÄCHLICH etwas vorgefallen und Shaddis war dafür verantwortlich wenn auch nur indirekt.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sie werden natürlich bestraft. Wir müssen ihnen beibringen, dass sie dem Gesetz nicht in der Hoffnung trotzen können, den Konsequenzen zu entgehen. Aber ich bin von Dir enttäuscht, Diakon. Du wusstest davon. Du hättest es verhindern können.[PARAGRAPH:1]Shaddis senkte verschämt den Kopf. Er hatte es gewusst, hielt es aber nicht für notwendig zu handeln. Ein früheres Einschreiten hätte erschreckend aufwendige Maßnahmen erfordert. Daher hatte er das Problem in der Hoffnung ignoriert, dass es sich von selber erledigen würde. Stattdessen ist es eskaliert und nun würden die Aufräumarbeiten ein einziger Schlamassel werden.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel erhob sich schwebend. Als er dies tat erstrahlte der Raum in einem vielfarbigen Licht. Dieser Anblick hörte nie auf, Shaddis zu beeindrucken. In jedem Bereich der Wände war nun jeweils ein riesiges Fenster, welches Ausblick auf die weit unten liegende Landschaft gewährte. Es war, als ob sich der Raum an der Spitze eines unglaublich hohen Turmes befände. Aber die Aussicht war nicht überall gleich. Durch ein Fenster konnte man nichts als Berge sehen, bedeckt mit Schnee und Eis. Ein anderes Fenster zeigte Hügellandschaften, Felder und blühende Weiden. Ein Drittes schaute über endlose Wüsten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der engelsgleiche Herrscher der Bannor glitt zu einem Fenster hinüber, welches das ausufernde urbane Bild der Hauptstadt zeigte. Schweigend stand er dort eine lange Zeit, die Arme hinter seinem Rücken verschränkt. Shaddis schwieg ebenfalls. Ein Gespräch mit Sabathiel zu führen war eine frustrierende Angelegenheit - der Engel wusste was man sagen wollte, noch bevor man den Mund aufmachte. Daher wartete der Diakon geduldig auf seinen Meister.[PARAGRAPH:1] Letztendlich entfuhr Sabathiel ein langer, schaudernder Seufzer, der Shaddis an das Geräusch eines Windes erinnerte, der durch einen Gebirgspass pfiff. Immer noch zur Stadt gewandt begann Sabathiel zu sprechen:[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich mache Dir keinen Vorwurf. Du bist schließlich nur ein Mensch. Ihr seid alle nur Menschen. Unbezahlbare Werkzeuge im Dienste Junils, aber trotzdem bloß sterbliche Hüllen, fehlbar und geneigt im falschen Moment zu zögern. Manchmal, Freund, muss Gnade zugunsten von Frieden, Stabilität und Gesetz zurückstecken. Dies war so ein Moment und du hast versäumt ihn zu bemerken. Du hast die Grenzen deiner menschlichen Fähigkeiten erreicht. Ich bin nicht wütend auch habe ich keinen wirklichen Grund, enttäuscht zu sein. Aber Du bist ein Zögling meines Volkes, von meinen Kindern, welche ich in das Licht führte und welche ich während Mulcarns Herrschaft beschützte... Ich glaube, ich habe einfach zu viel von Dir erwartet."[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel hielt inne, vielleicht um seine Gedanken zu sammeln. Wer weiß? Sein Geist schien auf einer völlig anderen Wahrnehmungsebene zu arbeiten. Während Menschen von Entscheidung zu Entscheidung stolperten, immer in der Hoffnung die best mögliche getroffen zu haben, wusste der Engel einfach. Er war in der Lage zu absoluter Gnadenlosigkeit, Tücke und ausgesprochener Grausamkeit; aber das Resultat jeder von Sabathiel getroffener Entscheidung würde immer besser sein, als jede erdenkliche alternative Handlungsweise. Der Engel, so herzlos und falsch er im Moment auch erscheinen mochte, hatte immer Recht. Auf einmal begann das Fenster viele andere Aussichten zu zeigen, welche in unglaublicher Geschwindigkeit vorbeizogen.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So viel zu beobachten. So viele, für die man Sorgen muss. So viele Dinge, die schief gehen können. Ich wünschte... oh wie ich wünschte eine weitaus direktere Rolle in den Angelegenheiten meines Volkes einnehmen zu können. Ereignisse wie diese würden nicht passieren. Ich wäre da, um sie zu verhindern. Aber ich bin nicht stark genug. Noch nicht. Ich muss den Rest an Kraft aufsparen, den ich noch besitze. Eines Tages, wenn Du nicht mehr da bist vielleicht. Aber schon bald werde ich es brauchen. Wir werden es alle brauchen."
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Shaddis scivolò silenziosamente dentro la stanza. Anche se non paragonabile alle vaste anticamere e alle imponenti sale delle parte pubblica delle Sale di Sabathiel, la stanza era grande abbastanza, grosso modo cubica e sei mentri buoni dal pavimento al tetto. Il tetto era a volta, con le colonne di supporto costruite dentro le quattro mura, che dividevano il muro in tre parti.[PARAGRAPH:1]La stanza era inoltre immersa nell'oscurità, il che attira l'attenzione sulla grande figura che giace su un letto di pietra lavorata al centro della stanza in quanto essa emette un debole bagliore. Sabathiel stava di nuovo dormendo. Probabilmente stava ancora dormendo da quando Shaddis gli ha parlato l'ultima volta, ovvero due settimane prima. [PARAGRAPH:1]Non stava veramente dormendo, Shaddis riflettè. Non era sicuro di cosa fosse. Era come se il corpo di Sabathiel era li, sul letto di pietra, ma senza la sua mente e la sua anima. Il Diacono dei Venti non aveva mai chiesto a Sabathiel dove andava la sua mente quando giaceva in quel modo. Ma non era sicuro di volerlo sapere. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mentre Shaddis si avvicinava, ci fu un suono come di una lunga inspirazione, e Sabathiel si sedette in posizione verticale con sorprendente rapidità. [PARAGRAPH:1]"È successo qualcosa".[PARAGRAPH:1]La voce sembrava un milione di voci che parlavano dolcemente allo stesso tempo, e aveva un tono d'accusa e di certezza simultanea che fecero infuriare Shaddis. Sabathiel lo stava analizzando, probabilmente scoprendo cosa non andava ancora prima che Shaddis potesse dirlo. E l'angelo aveva ragione, sia nella dichiarazione che nel tono accusatorio. Qualcosa ERA successo, e la colpa era di Shaddis, anche se indirettamente. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Saranno puniti, ovviamente. Dobbiamo insegnargli che non possono sfidare la Legge e sperare di evitarne le conseguenze. Ma sono deluso da te, diacono. Sapevi di questo. Avresti potuto fermarlo prima". [PARAGRAPH:1]Shaddis chinò il capo per la vergogna. Lui sapeva, ma non l'aveva ritenuto importante. Occuparsene nella fase iniziale avrebbe richiesto l'adozione di misure terribili. Quindi aveva ignorato il problema, sperando che si risolvesse da solo. E invece era esploso. Ora sistemarlo sarebbe stato un casino.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel si alzò in piedi. E mentre lui si alzava la stanza si riempì di una luce multicolore. Shaddis ne rimaneva sempre stupito. Ogni sezione del muro era ora un'enorme finestra che dava su su un panorama molto più in basso. Era come se la stanza fosse in cima a una torre incredibilmente alta. Ma il panorama non era uniforme. Ogni finestra si affacciava su un paesaggio diverso: in una si potevano vedere solo montagne, ghiaccio e neve. Un'altra mostrava delle colline, dei campi e dei pacifici pascoli. Una terza dava su un deserto senza fine. [PARAGRAPH:1]L'angelico sovrano dei Bannor andò verso la finestra che mostrava il vasto panorama urbano della capitale. E rimase li in silenzio, con le mani incrociate dietro la schiena, per un pò di tempo. Shaddis non parlò. Discutere con Sabathiel era una cosa frustrante, l'angelo sapeva cosa stavi per dire ancora prima che la dicessi effettivamente, e di solito rispondeva ancora prima che tu aprissi la bocca. Quindi il Diacono aspettò pazientemente che fosse il suo signore a rompere il silenzio. [PARAGRAPH:1]Alla fine, Sabathiel emise un lungo sospiro. Ricordò a Shaddis di un vento che fischia attraverso un passo di montagna. Ancora guardando la sua città, Sabathiel iniziò a parlare: [PARAGRAPH:1]"Non è colpa tua. Dopotutto, sei solo umano. Siete tutti umani. Degli strumenti inestimabili al servizio di Junil, ma pur sempre di carne mortale e inclini a commettere errori. A volte, amico mio, la pietà deve essere messa da parte per la pace, la stabilità e la Legge. Questo era uno di quiei momenti, e tu non sei riuscito a capirlo. Hai raggiunto i limiti delle tue capacità umane. Non sono arrabbiato. Non ho neppure alcuna ragione per rimanere deluso. Ma tu sei il prodotto del mio popolo, dei miei figli, di coloro che ho guidato dentro la luce e di coloro che ho protetto durante il regno di Mulcarn. Credo... Credo di aver preteso troppo da te". [PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel fece una pausa. Forse per riordinare i suoi pensieri. Chi lo sa? La sua mente sembrava lavorare su un piano completamente diverso. Mentre gli umani dovevano convivere con le loro scelte, sperando di aver fatto la scelta migliore, l'angelo sapeva semplicemente quali fossero. Era capace di essere completamente spietato, di ingannare e di essere estremamente crudele, ma i risultati di un'azione ordinata da Sabathiel erano sempre migliori di qualsiasi alternativa possibile. L'angelo, per quanto poteva sembrare senza cuore e in errore in quei momenti, aveva sempre ragione. La finestra improvvisamente iniziò a mostrare diversi panorami, cambiando a una velocità sorprendente. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Così tanto da guardare. Cosi tanti di cui occuparsi. Così tante cose che possono andare storte. Vorrei cosi tanto poter prendere parte in maniera più diretta negli affari del mio popolo. Queste cose non accadrebbero. Ci penserei io a fermarle. Ma non sono abbastanza forte. Non ancora. Devo conservare quel poco di forza che mi rimane. Un giorno, quando non ci sarai più, forse, ma un giorno a breve, ne avrò bisogno. Ne avremo tutti bisogno".
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Shaddis slipped quietly into the room. Although not comparable to the vast antechambers and lofty halls of the public part of the Halls of Sabathiel, the room was large enough, roughly cubic and a good six meters from floor to roof. The roof was vaulted, with supporting columns built into the four walls, dividing each wall into three segments.[PARAGRAPH:1]The room was also plunged into darkness, something which simply drew your attention to the fact that the huge figure lying on a carved stone bed in the centre of the room was emitting a faint glow. Sabathiel was sleeping again. He'd probably been sleeping since last Shaddis spoke to him, two weeks ago. [PARAGRAPH:1]It wasn't really sleep, Shaddis reflected. He wasn't quite sure what it was. It was like Sabathiel's body was there, on the stone bed, but his mind and soul weren't. The Deacon of Winds had never asked Sabathiel where his mind went when he lay like that. He wasn't sure he wanted to know. [PARAGRAPH:1]As Shaddis approached, there was a sucking sound, like a sharp intake of air, and Sabathiel sat bolt upright with startling suddenness. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Something has happened."[PARAGRAPH:1]The voice sounded like a million voices speaking softly at the same time, and it carried a note of simultaneous accusation and certainty that infuriated Shaddis. Sabathiel was scrutinizing him, probably finding out what was wrong even before Shaddis had a chance to say it. And the angel was right, both in the statement and in the accusatory tone. Something HAD happened, and Shaddis was at fault, albeit indirectly. [PARAGRAPH:1]"They will be punished, of course. We must teach them that they cannot defy Law and hope to avoid repercussions. But I am disappointed in you, deacon. You knew about this. You could have stopped it earlier." [PARAGRAPH:1]Shaddis bowed his head in shame. He had known, but he hadn't found it important. Dealing with it at this early stage would have required taking appalling measures. So he had left the problem alone, hoping it would burn itself out. Instead it had exploded. The cleaning up would be a mess.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel floated to his feet. As he did, the room erupted with multi-hued light. The sight never ceased to awe Shaddis. Every section of wall was now a huge window looking out across a landscape far below. It was as if the room was at the top of an impossibly tall tower. But the view was not uniform. Each window overlooked a different landscape: In one window, all you could see was mountains, ice and snow. Another showed rolling hills, fields and peaceful pastures. A third looked out across an endless desert. [PARAGRAPH:1]The angelic ruler of the Bannor drifted across to a window that showed the sprawling urban vista of the capital. He stood there in silence, his hands clasped behind his back, for quite some time. Shaddis didn't speak. Holding a conversation with Sabathiel was a frustrating affair-the angel knew what you were going to say before you said it, and generally answered before you even had a chance to open your mouth. So the Deacon waited patiently for his master to break the silence. [PARAGRAPH:1]Finally, Sabathiel let out a long, shuddering sigh. It reminded Shaddis of a wind whistling through a mountain pass. Still facing his city, Sabathiel started to speak: [PARAGRAPH:1]"I don't blame you. After all, you're only human. You're all only human. Invaluable tools in Junil's service, but still only mortal flesh, fallible and prone to faltering. Sometimes, my friend, mercy must take a back seat to peace, stability and Law. This was one of those times, and you failed to recognize it. You reached the limits of your human capacities. I'm not angry. I have no real reason to be disappointed either. But you are a product of my people, of my children, those whom I lead into the light, those I protected through Mulcarn's reign. I suppose... I suppose I have expected too much from you." [PARAGRAPH:1]Sabathiel paused. To gather his thoughts, perhaps. Who knew? His mind appeared to work on an entirely different plane. While humans had to stumble through their choices, hoping the one they made was the best possible, the angel simply knew. He was capable of total mercilessness, of deceit and exquisite cruelty, but the results of an action commanded by Sabathiel would always be better than any alternative course of action could have brought. The angel, however heartless and wrong he seemed at the time, was always right. The window suddenly started showing many different views, flickering past at an astonishing speed. [PARAGRAPH:1]"So much to watch. So many to care for. So many things that can go awry. I wish, oh, how I wish, I could take a more direct part in the affairs of my people. These things would not happen. I would be there to stop them. But I am not strong enough. Not yet. I need to conserve what little strength I still possess. Someday, after you are gone, perhaps, but some day soon, I will need it. We will all need it."

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Bannor society men condemned to death for breaking oaths can be given temporary reprieve from execution if they serve in the military. They sacrifice their title, property, relationships and even their name. To everyone else it is as if they died on the gallows.[PARAGRAPH:1]These men are known as Forsworn Brothers, and no matter their valor or accomplishment their execution awaits them at the end of the war. Their only reward is the opportunity to die in battle instead of in a criminals noose, and they pursue this goal with relentless devotion.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Au sein de la société Bannor, les hommes condamnés à mort pour avoir violé leurs serments peuvent disposer d'un répit temporaire s'ils s'engagent dans l'armées. Ils sacrifient leur titre, leur patrimoine, leurs relations et même leur nom. Pour le reste du monde, c'est comme s'ils étaient morts pendus.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ces hommes sont connus commes les Frères Parjures et, indépendamment de leur bravoure et de leurs actions, l'exécution les attend toujours à la fin de la guerre. La seule récompense qu'ils peuvent obtenir est la mort au combat plutôt qu'au bout d'une corde ; ils poursuivent cet objectif avec une dévotion sans relâche.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In der Gesellschaft der Bannor können Männer, die wegen Eidbruchs zum Tode verurteilt worden sind, eine einstweilige Begnadigung erhalten, wenn sie in der Armee dienen. Sie opfern ihre Titel, ihren Besitz, ihre Beziehungen und manchmal auch ihren Namen. Für alle anderen ist es so, als ob sie am Galgen gestorben wären.[PARAGRAPH:1]Diese Männer sind bekannt als die Meineidigen Brüder, und unabhängig von ihrem Mut und ihren Leistungen erwartet sie am Ende des Krieges ihre Exekution. Ihre einzige Belohnung ist die Chance, in der Schlacht zu sterben statt in einer Schlinge um ihren Hals und sie streben dieses Ziel mit unbeirrbarer Hingabe an.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Nella società Bannor i condannati a morte per aver infranto dei giuramenti possono ottenere una sospensione della pena se servono nell'esercito. Rinunciano al loro titolo, alle loro prorpietà, alle loro relazioni e persino al loro nome. Per tutti gli altri è come se morisserò sulla forca.[PARAGRAPH:1]Queste persone sono conosciute come Fratelli Rinnegati, e non importa il loro valore o i loro risultati la loro esecuzione li attende alla fine della guerra. La loro unica ricompensa è la possibilità di morire in battaglia invece che con il cappio, e perseguono questo obiettivo con un'implacabile dedizione.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Discipline[\BOLD][NEWLINE]What other word comes to mind when thinking of Bannor soldiers?[NEWLINE]You have to be disciplined when fighting against the armies of hell.[NEWLINE]And where does discipline come from? Training. And who does the training?[NEWLINE][BOLD]The captains[\BOLD].[PARAGRAPH:2]The Bannor have taken the art that is leadership and turned it into a science. There are stores of records of Bannor captains defeating enemy forces who are twice their size and better equipped. I need not remind my readers of the slaughter at Boulderment Pass. Such victories were common amongst the best captains.[PARAGRAPH:2][ITALICS]Surviving page from a Dural book of History[\ITALICS]

While the rules of their order prevent the use of any ranged or bladed weapons, a solid hit from a staff-wielding cleric has ended many an enemy of law and order.

TEXT.French: Donal Lugh

TEXT.English: Donal is the hero of the Bannor and a legendary slayer of demons and the undead. He is able to recruit units in cities and, unlike the Great Commander, is not sacrificed by doing so. If Donal proves the legends true, and kills demons and the undead, he will regain the ability to recruit and can build a huge army if he survives his own battles.[PARAGRAPH:2]The hound that tracked him almost looked normal, until it turned and growled. Half of the face was rotted away, and the skull beneath was scratched and chipped, with a dark pit for an eye socket. But it had no trouble seeing its prey. It leapt for Donal's throat.[PARAGRAPH:1]This was far from the first Hellhound Donal had seen. Reflex took over, and he dropped and rolled to avoid the fangs. His crude weapons flew to his hands. Donal and the hound circled each other, feinting and pulling back, until in a flash it was over. Donal dodged the lunge, and sunk his blade into the demon's neck, pinning it to the ground. It growled and thrashed about almost comically, trying to free itself and continue the attack.[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'mon, boy, play dead," Donal said, slamming his shield down upon the hound's skull. Both shattered, and the thrashing stopped. "That's a good dog."[PARAGRAPH:1]He didn't laugh at his jokes any longer. He had stopped amusing himself some time ago. Ten years or a thousand, he had no idea and had stopped caring. Since his people left Hell, there was no one else to laugh either, and yet still he quipped as he grimly fought the inhabitants of this realm. In the home of the King of Despair, his biggest battle was maintaining the one thing that sustained him, hope.[PARAGRAPH:2]"We have no hope, Capria. We must abandon the siege."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Capria turned to face her nephew. "We cannot, Mattius! You heard what I heard from Fanariel's lips. The Sheaim have made a breakthrough. With Agares' guidance.' We must press on!" Capria trembled as she spoke, her aging frame failing her more and more lately. Perhaps she would be steadier if she met her council without full battle armor on, but to be war leader of the Bannor and not be ever battle ready?[PARAGRAPH:1]"Indeed we must," agreed the High Priest. He was young, much younger than the regent he addressed, but he spoke with supreme confidence. "The heresies stemming from Galveholm are provocation enough to mobilize. Sabathiel therefore sees no reason for us to even associate with elven brigands like this Fanariel."[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius snorted. "I'm sure Sabathiel knows a better way to get a spy into Sheaim lands, but he hasn't been exactly forthcoming lately."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Does the Head of House Venerat doubt the authority of the priesthood to speak for..."[PARAGRAPH:1]"What Mattius was pointing out, Elmin," Capria jumped in, "is that we need to prioritize our missions. The Clans have been building strength, our ambassadors have been expelled from the Lanun capital, and"[PARAGRAPH:1]The war council was interrupted by a tremendous quake, throwing them all to the ground. Capria's reflexes triumphed over the limitations of age; she bounced to her feet and raced out of the tent. The camp was showing the benefits of Bannor discipline and were in formation around the commanders' tent, ready to repel the attack.[PARAGRAPH:1]But it was not an opening magical salvo for an attack. The army watched as the trees and brush on the hillside below them withered and died, the sun was obscured by a dreary haze, and fires erupted on the horizon. It was a scene Capria remembered well from her childhood, and nightmares ever since. 70 years ago they had escaped Hell, and now it had come for them.[PARAGRAPH:2]He had scoured this Hell looking for an escape. Never mind that it was an infinite plane, he swore he'd seen every inch of it twice. He had been chased every step of the way by the minions of Agares and Bhall, and managed to either elude them, or fend them off. All to see this day.[PARAGRAPH:1]Donal saw a portal to the mortal realm stretching out in the valley below him. A rift in dimensions, fluctuating wildly. And around it was arrayed an army of demons. Cavorting Imps, a contingent of Ruhin, a virtual city of manes... and the biggest Balor Donal had seen. And they were leaving. "Oh, not without me, you don't," he muttered as he started down the hillside. "I don't know where you're going, but it's got to be better than here."[PARAGRAPH:1]The demons marched through, as the rift slowly began to close.[PARAGRAPH:2]The demons were on the march. The first battle with them had caused the Bannor army to rout, and since then they had been pushed back to Tor Lehan, the nearest settlement to the corrupted lands. From its battlements Capria could see flames at the border to the Infernal lands all through the night. So far the priests' blessings had kept the corruption at bay, but not the corrupted. They surrounded the settlement, the demons that had haunted her in her youth. Only the most courageous soldiers remained to stand against them.[PARAGRAPH:1]The battle was joined at dawn. It quickly turned against them.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius stood alongside his aunt at the battle lines. "If I'm to die, I'm honored to do so beside one of the heroes of legends."[PARAGRAPH:1]Capria nodded, swinging her two-handed sword. "I'd rather live. But if the Bannor do not stand to face this dire threat, who will?" An image at the edge of her field of vision made her turn, coming face to face with a monstrous pit beast.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The trick to these beasties is to get them from behind," shouted an old friend as the Pit Beast was felled. "The wings limit their peripheral vision."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Who... my god, is that you? Donal Lugh?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"In the flesh, for a pleasant change."[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius gasped. "Then the legends... are all true? We are the Bannor of Sabathiel!"[PARAGRAPH:1]The tide of battle turned. The Bannor lost as many as survived, but the town was saved, and the forces of Hell pushed back for today. The news of the victory spread, shaming those who had fled, and inspiring a new generation. This was the war that Sabathiel had saved them for, and it was only beginning. But the first victory was theirs.

Er kann in Städten Einheiten rekrutieren und muss sich dabei, im Gegensatz zum Großen Feldherrn, nicht opfern. Wenn Donal die Legenden wahr werden lässt und Dämonen und Untote tötet, erhält er die Fähigkeit zu rekrutieren zurück und kann auf diese Weise eine große Armee aufstellen, vorausgesetzt, er überlebt seine eigenen Schlachten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Hund, der ihn verfolgte, sah fast normal aus, bis er knurrend seine andere Seite zeigte. Die Hälfte seines Gesichtes ist weggefault und der Schädel darunter ist zerkratzt und zerschlagen, mit einem dunklen Loch als Augenhöhle. Trotzdem sieht er seine Beute problemlos und so ging er Donal an die Gurgel.[PARAGRAPH:1]Es war beileibe nicht der erste Höllenhund, den Donal sah. Reflexartig ließ er sich fallen und rollte zur Seite, um den Reißzähnen zu entgehen. Schnell hatte er seine groben Waffen zu Hand. Donal und der Hund belauerten sich, täuschten Angriffe vor um gleich wieder zurückzuziehen, bis es plötzlich vorüber war. Donal täuschte einen Ausfallschritt an und trieb seine Klinge durch das Genick des Dämons in den Boden. Der knurrte und zappelte fast lachhaft, im Versuch, sich selbst zu befreien und den Angriff fortzusetzen.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Komm schon, spiele tot", sagte Donal und rammte dem Hund seinen Schild auf den Schädel. Beides ging zu Bruch, und das Zappeln hörte auf. "Guter Hund!"[PARAGRAPH:1]Er lachte schon lange nicht mehr über seine Witze, schon seit Jahren nicht mehr. Ob seit zehn oder tausend Jahren, das wusste er nicht und es interessierte ihn auch nicht mehr. Seit sein Volk die Hölle verlassen hatte, gab es niemanden mehr, mit dem er hätte lachen können, aber er machte noch immer seine Witze während er grimmig gegen die Bewohner dieses Reiches kämpfte. Im Gebiet des Königs der Verzweiflung war sein größter Kampf, das nicht zu verlieren, was ihn durchhalten ließ, seine Hoffnung.[PARAGRAPH:2]"Es gibt keine Hoffnung, Capria. Wir müssen die Belagerung aufgeben."[PARAGRAPH:1] Capria drehte sich zu ihrem Neffen um: "Wir können nicht, Mattius! Du hast gehört, was Fanariel sagte. Die Sheaim haben den Durchbruch geschafft. Mit Agares Hilfe. "Wir müssen weitermachen!" Capria zitterte als sie sprach, ihre alte Rüstung zerfiel langsam. Vielleicht hätte sie ruhiger gestanden, wenn sie ihrem Berater ohne ihre volle Kampfausrüstung gegenübergestanden hätte, aber was ist ein Kriegsführer der Bannor, der nicht allzeit zur Schlacht bereit ist?[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ja, das müssen wir" stimmte der Hohepriester zu. Er war jung, viel jünger als der Herrscher ihn schätzte, aber er sprach mit viel Zuversicht. "Die Ketzereien von Gaveholm sind Grund genug für die Mobilmachung. Sabathiel sieht darum noch nicht mal einen Grund, sich mit Banditen der Elfen, wie dieser Fanariel, zu verbünden."[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius schnaubte: "Ich bin sicher, Sabathiel kennt eine bessere Möglichkeit, einen Spion auf das Gebiet der Sheaim zu schmuggeln, aber er war letztens nicht gerade sehr miteilsam." [PARAGRAPH:1]"Zweifelt das Haupt des Hauses Venerat etwa an der Autorität der Priesterschaft, in seinem Namen zu sprechen?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Was Mattius sagen wollte, Elmin" unterbrach Capria, "wir müssen unsere Aufgaben nach Prioritäten einteilen. Die Klans sind stark geworden, unser Botschafter wurde aus der Hauptstadt der Lanun ausgewiesen und..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Versammlung wurde von einem gewaltigen Beben unterbrochen, das alle zu Boden warf. Caprias Reflexe besiegten die Schwäche des Alters, sie sprang auf und rannte aus dem Zelt. Das Lager war gemäß der straffen Organisation der Bannor in regelmäßigen Formationen um das Zelt der Heerführers herum aufgebaut, bereit Angriffe abzuwehren.[PARAGRAPH:1]Aber das war nicht die übliche magische Eröffnungssalve für einen Angriff. Die Armee sah, wie die Büsche und Bäume unterhalb am Hang verwelkten und starben, die Sonne wurde von einem trüben Dunst verhüllt und Flammen stiegen am Horizont auf. Capria kannte diese Szene aus ihrer Kindheit, und aus ihren Alpträumen. Vor 70 Jahren waren sie aus der Hölle geflohen und nun kam sie zu ihnen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Er hatte jeden Winkel der Hölle nach einem Ausgang durchsucht. Ungeachtet dass sie eine endlose Ebene ist, könnte er schwören, jeden Zentimeter mindestens zweimal gesehen zu haben. Er wurde auf Schritt und Tritt von den Günstlingen von Agares und Bhall verfolgt, konnte ihnen aber immer ausweichen oder sie abwehren. Und alles, nur um diesen Tag zu erleben.[PARAGRAPH:1]Donal sah das Portal zur Welt der Sterblichen im Tal unter ihm. Eine willkürlich flackernde Verwerfung der Dimensionen. Und drum herum eine Ansammlung von Dämonenarmeen. Herumspringend Kobolde, ein Aufgebot von Ruhin, eine virtuelle Stadt der Gester der Verfallenen... und den größten Balor, den Donal je gesehen hatte. Und sie gingen durch das Portal. "Nicht ohne mich, niemals!", murmelte er und rannte den Hügel hinunter. "Ich weiß nicht wohin ihr geht, aber es ist dort bestimmt besser als hier."[PARAGRAPH:1] Die Dämonen gingen hindurch, und die Verwerfung begann langsam sich zu schließen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Dämonen waren im Vorwärtsgang. Die erste Schlacht mit ihnen zwang die Bannorarmee in die Flucht, seitdem konnten sie aber bis Tor Lehan, die dem verdorbenen Land am nächsten gelegene Siedlung, zurückgedrängt werden. In ihren Schlachten konnte Capria die Flammen am Rand des infernalischen Landes die ganze Nacht über erblicken. Bis dahin hatten die Gebete der Priester das Verderben im Zaum halten können, nicht aber die Verdorbenen. Sie umzingelten die Siedlung, die Dämonen, die sie schon in ihrer Jungend gejagt hatten. Nur die mutigsten Soldaten stellten sich ihnen entgegen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Schlacht begann im Morgengrauen. Und bald lief alles gegen sie.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius stand neben seiner Tante im Schlachtfeld. Etwas in ihrem Augenwinkel ließ sie sich umdrehen, und sie stand einer monströsen Grubenbestie direkt gegenüber.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Der Trick ist, diese Biester von hinten zu bekommen." Rief ein alter Freund, als die Grubenbestie gefällt war. "Ihre Flügel schränken ihre Sicht ziemlich ein."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Wer... um alles in der Welt, bist du's? Donal Lugh?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Leibhaftig, ausnahmsweise."[PARAGRAPH:1]Mattius staunte: "Dann sind die Legenden... sind sie alle wahr? Wir sind die Bannor von Sabathiel!"[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Schlacht wendete sich. Die Bannor verloren die Hälfte ihrer Leute, aber die Stadt wurde gerettet und die Kräfte der Hölle wurden vorerst zurückgeschlagen. Die Kunde des Sieges verbreitete sich schnell, beschämte die, die geflohen waren und inspirierte eine ganz neue Generation. Für diesen Krieg hatte Sabathiel sie vorher beschützt, und das war erst der Anfang. Aber der erste Sieg gehörte ihnen.
TEXT.Italian: Donal è l'eroe dei Bannor e un leggendario sterminatore di demoni e non-morti. Può inoltre reclutare unità nelle città come i Grandi Comandanti. Aveva metà del muso completamente marcio e il teschio era graffiato e scheggiato, oltre ad avere una cavita oculare completamente vuota. Nonostante ciò non aveva problemi a vedere la sua preda. Le sue rozze armi "volarono" nelle sue mani. Donal e il segugio giravano in cerchio, fintando e inditreggiando fino a quando, in un attimo, era tutto finito. Donal schivò l'affondo, e affondò la sua lama nel collo del demone, inchiodandolo al terreno. Ringhiava e si agitava in maniera quasi comica, mentre cercava di liberarsi per continuare l'attacco.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Andiamo, piccolo, fai il morto" Donal disse mentre con lo scudo spaccava la testa del segugio. Da dieci o mille anni, non ne aveva idea e aveva smesso di importargli. Da quando il suo popolo aveva abbandonato l'Inferno non c'era nessun'altro con cui ridere comunque, eppure continuava a scherzare quando combatteva gli abitanti di questo reame. Nella casa del Re della Disperazione, la sua più grande battaglia era mantenere l'unica cosa che lo faceva andare avanti, la speranza.[PARAGRAPH:2]"Non abbiamo alcuna speranza, Capria. Era stato inseguito sempre dai servitori di Agares e Bhall, e riusci sempre a evitarli o respingerli. TEXT.English: The best hunters in Bannor lands are trained to track and kill not animals or great beasts but demons. They are the second line of defense against any otherworldly threat that managed to slip through the border.
